chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.simpara: Collaborative Project Developer is a very simple tool which enable us to collaborate on a project and maintain version. In a project it is very important to maintain versions and commit history, but the VCS which are available requires getting used to it. So, we started developing Collaborative Project Developer, which is very simple to use even for the first timer.

section.title: Motivation
section.simpara: We wanted to develop an application, which can help people start collaborating on project development without having to go learn all the technicalities of version control systems such as git and perforce. So, we started working on this simple versioning and collaborative tool.

section.title: Algorithm
section.simpara: In transaction processing, databases, and computer networking, the two-phase commit protocol (2PC) is a type of atomic commitment protocol (ACP). It is a distributed algorithm that coordinates all the processes that participate in a distributed atomic transaction on whether to commit or abort (roll back) the transaction (it is a specialized type of consensus protocol). The protocol achieves its goal even in many cases of temporary system failure (involving either process, network node, communication, etc. failures).

section.simpara: We are using node.js as our platform for developing this project. Alongwith node.js we are using some libraries to make development process faster.

section.title: Express
section.simpara: Express.js is a Node.js web application server framework, designed for building single-page, multi-page, and hybrid web applications.[1] It is the de facto standard server framework for node.js.[2] The original author, TJ Holowaychuck, described it as a Sinatra-inspired server,[3] meaning that it is relatively minimal with many features available as plugins.

section.title: Mongoose
section.simpara: Mongoose provides a straight-forward, schema-based solution to model your application data. It includes built-in type casting, validation, query building, business logic hooks and more, out of the box.

section.title: Passport
section.simpara: Passport is authentication middleware for Node.js. Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based web application. A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.

section.title: Codemirror
section.simpara: Codemirror is an open source library used for implementing code editor in web pages. We have used this plug-in for implementing the code editor that is displayed on our web-app.

chapter.title: Structure of the App
chapter.simpara: The structure of our app is inspired from MVC design philosophy. In MVC(Model View Controller), we separate what we have to show(views) from the main logic(controller). Similarly we also separate the models of underlying structure(models).
In our main app, we have the following directories/files.

section.title: Views
section.simpara: In this directory, we write all the files that we have to display. For example, index.html, login.html and signup.html.

section.title: Routes
section.simpara: In this directory, we write all the server routes. For example, to handle the request for approving the code by a particular team member, we wrote the following code in index.js in routes directory:

section.title: node_modules
section.simpara: This directory contains all the node libraries that we use in our app.

section.title: public
section.simpara: This directory houses static files(CSS or front end libraries) available.

section.title: bin
section.simpara: This directory houses the www script that contains environment configurations for our app.

section.title: app.js
section.simpara: This is our main server. This file is responsible for importing all the libraries, configuring the environment and starting the server.

section.title: Authentication
section.simpara: This app provides the feature for the authentic members to log into the app. This prevents the unauthorised users from making any changes or corrupting the files. For Authentication purpose, we use passport.js library.

section.title: Online Code Editor
section.simpara: Using codemirror library as a starting point, we were able to implement an online code editor for our app. This is a full-featured online-editor.

section.title: Syntax highlighting
section.simpara: The code-editor has the capability to highlight syntax of the code.

section.title: Auto-indent
section.simpara: This code editor also provides facility for auto-indenting codes, while changing lines.

section.title: Line Numbers
section.simpara: Line numbers also appear on our code-editor.

section.title: History of commits
section.simpara: Our app provides, commit history to be able to see previous commits and the person who made that commit.

section.title: Rollback to previous version
section.simpara: We also provide feature to roll-back to the previous version of the commit. If something goes wrong in the latest version of the project, we have the feature to roll-back to previous stable version of the project.
